book.title: JATS Tagging Instructions for NPG/Palgrave articles

preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: These Tagging Instructions describe NPG's preferred XML tagging style for journal article submissions in NISO JATS Journal Publishing DTD. All deliveries made to NPG must conform to the provisions of this document.

The Tagging Instructions are divided into separate chapters. Each chapter describes separate rules that must be followed when creating NPG-style compliant XML. Many of the rules are related, but none are duplicated from one chapter to another.

listitem.para: General tagging practice: These style rules apply to structured data tagging at a very broad level and include emphasised text, mathematics, and special characters.
Document structures: This chapter describes specific parts of XML documents like figures, tables and author/affiliation relationships. It includes examples of XML tagging.

Elements: This chapter describes style rules for specific XML elements and their attributes. Only elements for which NPG has a style rule are described in this section. Refer to the JATS Tag Library for descriptions of all elements available in the DTD.

preface.para: In addition to these chapters, all updates to the Tagging Instructions will be documented in the Update History.

simplesect.title: A note on presentation
simplesect.para: Elements are shown within angled brackets. Attributes are preceeded by the @ sign. Both are shown in a monospace font to distinguish them from regular text.

simplesect.title: Packaging format
simplesect.para: XML files should be uploaded to the NPG XML Gateway for validation against DTD and Schematron rules. Associated binary files (images, pdfs etc) should be submitted to the ftp site. This is likely to change in the future with all files submitted together to the Content Gateway.

section.title: Online-only Academic journals
section.para: For our new online-only Academic Journals (Horticulture Research, Molecular Therapy – Methods & Clinical Development), the following conventions apply:

listitem.para: article assets (pdf, XML, graphical files, supplementary files) will be named for the article id with an identifying suffix as appropriate
all filenames and suffixes must be lower case
a dash will be required between image/supplementary information file names and their identifiers
Examples:
nmstr201322.xml—article XML
nmstr201322.pdf—article pdf
nmstr201322-f1.jpg—a figure image [where a figure has multiple subimages, use further suffixes 'a', 'b' etc e.g. nmstr201322-f2a.gif, nmstr201322-f2b.gif]
nmstr201322-pf1.ppt—a figure slide [again, where a figure has multiple subimages, use further suffixes 'a', 'b' etc e.g. nmstr201322-pf2a.ppt, nmstr201322-pf2b.ppt]
nmstr201322-i1.jpg—an illustration
nmstr201322-t1.jpg—a table image
nmstr201322-pt1.ppt—a table slide
nmstr201322-s1.xxx—supplementary information

section.title: DTD
section.para: The XML should conform to the JATS Journal Publishing DTD, version 1.0 incorporating the Oasis table model. The DTD is available from the stable ftp site: ftp://ftp.ncbi.nih.gov/pub/jats/publishing/1.0/
The main module of the DTD we use is "JATS-journalpublishing-oasis-article1.dtd". It imports the subordinate modules. For the schema to work, all modules must be in the same directory.
The complete JATS Tag Library is available on the web: http://jats.nlm.nih.gov/publishing/tag-library/1.0/index.html

section.title: DOCTYPE declaration
section.para: Set the PUBLIC identifier to "-//NLM//DTD JATS (Z39.96) Journal Publishing DTD with OASIS Tables v1.0 20120330//EN".
Set the SYSTEM identifier to "JATS-journalpublishing-oasis-article1.dtd".
section.programlisting: <!DOCTYPE article PUBLIC "-//NLM//DTD JATS (Z39.96) Journal Publishing DTD with OASIS Tables v1.0 20120330//EN" "JATS-journalpublishing-oasis-article1.dtd">

section.title: Emphasised text
section.para: As a rule, use emphasised text markup (, , , etc) only to set off a piece of information. Do not set entire elements in emphasised text. For example, if a is set completely in boldface, do not use the <bold>. However, if a title has a word or some words set in boldface for emphasis, tag those words using <bold>. Mainly this will apply to <title>, <p> in <abstract>, <label> and entries in <oasis:thead>. It might also appear in <aff> and "special" sections, like <ack>.

section.title: Empty elements
section.para: Do not use empty elements for the purpose of formatting, except where stated below. All required elements should have content.

section.title: Links
section.para: Tag all internal links within the document (e.g. tables, figures, display formulae) with the <xref> element and include the appropriate @ref-type. See <xref>.

Tag all links to related articles (e.g. from a correction to the corrected article) with <related-article> and include the appropriate @related-article-type, and citation information. See <related-article>.
Tag all external links with <ext-link> and include the appropriate @ext-link-type. See <ext-link>.

section.title: Mathematics
section.para: Tag all display formulae with MathML markup. MathML 2.0 is included in the JATS DTD.
Tag an inline formula with MathML markup when it cannot be represented by regular article elements and/or Unicode characters.
An image of the formula is not required.
Do not set mathematics as <tex-math>.
Use <mml:math> to tag mathematical expressions only. Do not use it to tag single characters.
See Formulae for sample markup.

section.title: Use of Unicode
section.para: Do not use named character entities within JATS markup, apart from the predefined XML entities (< for <, > for >, and & for &).

Tag non-ASCII characters with their Unicode hex number in character entity style (e.g. × for × and g̃ for g̃). Unicode values can be with or without leading zeroes, it makes no difference to our systems.

Do not use values from the Private Use Areas: xE000–xF8FF, xF0000–xFFFFD, and x100000–x10FFFD. Do not use Unicode values designated as control codes. These ranges include but are not limited to x0000–0020, x0080–x009F.

chapter.title: Document structures
chapter.para: These Document Objects refer to pieces of the XML documents that define a single concept (author/affiliation relationships, copyright information etc) and often include several XML elements in their tagging.

sect1.title: Article
sect1.para: See <article> for information on tagging the root <article> element.
All articles will contain <front> and most will contain <body>, <back> and <floats-group>. More detailed information on these sections is given below.
<sub-article> may be used occasionally for correspondence and reviews.
Do not use <response>.

sect1.title: Front
sect1.para: <front> should contain <journal-meta> and <article-meta>. <notes> may be used in <front> in a couple of special cases [but should not be used for online-only journals].

sect2.title: Journal metadata
sect2.para:
<journal-meta> contains minimal journal metadata:
pcode/journal id
journal title
ISSN(s), and
publisher name
See <journal-id>, <journal-title-group>, <issn>, and <publisher>.
Examples:
sect2.programlisting:
<journal-meta> <journal-id journal-id-type="publisher">nutd</journal-id> <journal-title-group> <journal-title>Nutrition & Diabetes</journal-title> </journal-title-group> <issn pub-type="epub">2044-4052</issn> <publisher> <publisher-name>Nature Publishing Group</publisher-name> </publisher> </journal-meta>
<journal-meta> <journal-id journal-id-type="publisher">sth</journal-id> <journal-title-group> <journal-title>Social Theory and Health</journal-title> </journal-title-group> <issn pub-type="ppub">1477-8211</issn> <issn pub-type="epub">1477-822X</issn> <publisher> <publisher-name>Palgrave Macmillan</publisher-name> </publisher> </journal-meta>
sect2.para: Do not use <contrib-group>, <aff>, <aff-alternatives>, <issn-l>, <isbn>, <notes>, or <self-uri> within <journal-meta>.

sect2.title: Article metadata
sect2.para: The following information is given in the order that it should appear in <article-meta>.

sect3.title: Article ids
sect3.para: NPG/Palgrave articles should all have two <article-id>s:

listitem.para: @pub-id-type="publisher-id"—the article filename
@pub-id-type="doi"—the full article DOI

sect3.para: Example:

sect3.title: Article categories
sect3.para: NPG/Palgrave articles should all have <article-categories>.
Do not use <series-text> or <series-title> in <article-categories>.
Do not use @specific-use or @xml:lang on <subj-group>.
Do not use @id on <subject>.

sect4.title: Article heading and article category code
sect4.para: All articles should have an article heading and category code captured within <article-categories>.

The article heading (e.g. "Article", "Brief Communication", "Corrigendum") should be captured within <subj-group subj-group-type="article-heading"> and child element <subject content-type="article-heading">.
The article category code (which is also the main <article> @article-type code) should be captured within <subj-group subj-group-type="category"> and child element <subject> with no attributes.
Example:

sect4.title: Subject codes
sect4.para: Subject codes are provided by NPG and are a numerical representation of the key ontological terms covered by the article.
All the subject codes should be captured within one <subj-group subj-group-type="subject"> element with child elements <subject content-type="npg.subject">.
There are three parts to each code: version, id and path, which must always be stated in the XML. Each one is captured as <named-content> with the @content-type value giving the part name.
The current "version" is 1.0, the "id" is always the final number in the "path" and the "path" gives the full heirarchy of terms.
Do not use any other attributes on <named-content>.
Example:

sect3.title: Article title
sect3.para: The required <title-group> element should not contain <trans-title-group>. Examples will be given of when other child elements can be used.
If an article has a running title, <alt-title alt-title-type="running-title"> should be used.
Example:
sect3.programlisting: <article-title>Serum adiponectin level is not only decreased in metabolic syndrome but also in borderline metabolic abnormalities</article-title> <alt-title alt-title-type="running-title">Adiponectin and borderline abnormalities</alt-title>

sect3.title: Contributors and affiliations
sect3.para: All NPG/Palgrave articles should have <contrib-group> to capture the article authors. <contrib-group> should only contain one or more <contrib>, do not use any other child elements.
Each <contrib> should have @contrib-type (with values "author" or "editor") and @corresp (with values "yes" or "no").
Each <contrib> should also contain an <xref> to their affiliation details (except for correction articles where this is not required).
If a contributor has @corresp="yes" then an <xref> to the correspondence information should be also be given.
<xref> should also be used for links to other notes about the authors, e.g. equal contribution information.
The affilations should be gathered together as separate <aff> elements after <contrib-group> and not included as a child element of <contrib>.
If a contributor has an ORCID reference, this should be captured as <contrib-id> with @contrib-id-type="orcid".
Affiliations are not required for correction articles (corrigendum, addendum, erratum, correction), unless the correction is to the affiliation details.
Examples:
sect3.programlisting: <contrib-group> <contrib contrib-type="author" corresp="yes"> <name> <surname>Newton</surname> <given-names>R L</given-names> <suffix>Jr</suffix> </name> <xref ref-type="aff" rid="a1"/> <xref ref-type="corresp" rid="c1"/> </contrib> <contrib contrib-type="author" corresp="no"> <name> <surname>Caron-Jobin</surname> <given-names>M</given-names> </name> <xref ref-type="aff" rid="a1"/> <xref ref-type="aff" rid="a2"/> <xref ref-type="author-notes" rid="n1"> <sup>6</sup> </xref> </contrib> <contrib contrib-type="author" corresp="no"> <contrib-id contrib-id-type="orcid">http://orcid.org/0000-0003-0110-324X</contrib-id> <name> <surname>Dahly</surname> <given-names>D L</given-names> </name> <xref ref-type="aff" rid="a1"/> </contrib> </contrib-group> <aff id="a1"><institution>Endocrinology and Genomics, Laval University</institution>, <addr-line content-type="city">Québec City</addr-line>, <addr-line content-type="state">Québec </addr-line>, <country>Canada</country></aff> <aff id="a2"><institution>Physical Check up Center, Sumitomo Hospital</institution>, <addr-line content-type="city">Osaka</addr-line>, <country>Japan</country></aff>
sect3.para: See <xref> for further information on marking up author-related links.

sect3.title: Author notes
sect3.para: <author-notes> contains correspondence information, any conflict of interest statement, author contribution information and any other author-related notes (e.g. equal contribution information).
Do not use , <label> or <p> in <author-notes>.
Example (further details are given below):
sect3.programlisting:
t7908077@mail.ncku.edu.tw paulo@mail.ncku.edu.tw

These authors contributed equally to this work.

The authors declare no conflict of interest.

M-C Hsu designed research, performed experiments, analyzed data and wrote the paper; C-S Chang and K-T Lee participated in research design, collection of clinical data and patient samples; Y-S Tsai and P-H Kuo participated in research design and collection of patient samples; H-Y Sun participated in research design and discussion; K-C Young participated in research design, discussion and paper-editing; C-H Wu contributed to research design, discussion and paper-editing, collection of clinical data and patient samples.

sect4.title: Correspondence information
sect4.para: Details of the address and/or email of a corresponding author should be contained in <corresp> and not in <fn fn-type="corresp">.
Use a separate <corresp> element for each corresponding author when different email addresses are given.
Each <corresp> should have an @id which should follow the format of "c" + number.
Where the author's name/title is given at the beginning of the address, mark this up as <named-content content-type="author">
Examples:
sect4.programlisting:
<corresp id="c1"><named-content content-type="author">Professor W-S Choi</named-content>, <institution>Department of Family Medicine, Seoul St Mary’s Hospital, College of Medicine, The Catholic University of Korea</institution>, <addr-line content-type="street">505 Banpo-Dong, Seocho-Gu</addr-line>, <addr-line content-type="city">Seoul</addr-line> <addr-line content-type="zip">137-701</addr-line>, <country>Korea</country>. E-mail: <email xlink:href="kolpos@naver.com">kolpos@naver.com</email></corresp>
<corresp id="c1"><email xlink:href="hrmaskf@hkucc.hku.hk">hrmaskf@hkucc.hku.hk</email></corresp> <corresp id="c2"><email xlink:href="tgeorge@hkucc.hku.hk">tgeorge@hkucc.hku.hk</email></corresp>

sect4.title: Conflict of interest statement
sect4.para: Where a conflict of interest statement is given, it should be captured as <fn @fn-type="conflict"> in <author-notes> and not as a section in <back>.

<fn> should also have @specific-use with values "no-conflict" (where there is no conflict) or "conflict" (where there is a conflict). "conflict" should also be used even if only one author has declared it.
Examples:
sect4.programlisting:
The authors declare no conflict of interest.

RJS has received grant support from Zafgen and Ethicon Endo-Surgery. RJS also currently has stock/stock options with Zafgen and consults for Zafgen, Eli Lilly and Ethicon Endo-Surgeries. DAS has received grant support from Ethicon Endo- Surgery, Roche, Mannkind, and Pfizer. The other authors declare no conflict of interest.

sect4.title: Contribution information
sect4.para: Where author contribution information is given, it should be captured as <fn @fn-type="con"> in <author-notes> and not as a section in <back> or <ack>.
Example:
sect4.programlisting: Dr E Shyong Tai and Dr Jeannette Lee helped in the conception and design the study. Dr Chin Meng Khoo, Maudrene Tan and Wu Yi helped conduct the literature review, data analysis and preparation of the text. Dr Daniel Wai and Dr Subramaniam Tavintharan helped in the final approval of the manuscript.

sect4.title: Other types of author notes
sect4.para: Any other types of author notes (e.g. equal contribution information, current address) should be captured as <fn> without @fn-type in <author-notes>.
Each <fn> should have an @id which should follow the format of "n" + number.
<label> should be used as the number/symbol used cannot be derived from the @id.
Example:
sect4.programlisting: These authors contributed equally to this work.

sect3.title: Publication dates
sect3.para: For online-only journals, only one <pub-date> is required:

listitem.para: @pub-type="epub"—the online publishing date of the article. This should have <day>, <month> and <year> child elements.

sect3.para: Example:

sect3.title: Volume, issue and page information
sect3.para: For our new online-only Academic Journals (Horticulture Research and Molecular Therapy – Methods & Clinical Development), only include volume and elocation information.
There is no need to give issue or first page information.
Do not use the prefix 'e' on the elocation-id value.
Example:
For online-only journals which follow a volume and issue structure, include volume, issue and first page information.
Example:

sect3.title: Historical dates
sect3.para: <history> should be used to capture the received, revised and accepted dates of an article manuscript (where these have been provided).
<date> @date-type values should be:

listitem.para: "received"—the date the article was received (REQUIRED)
"rev-recd"—the date a revision to the article was received (optional, but may be more than one)
"accepted"—the date the article was accepted (REQUIRED)

sect3.title: Copyright and permissions
sect3.para: All NPG/Palgrave articles should have <copyright-year> and <copyright-holder> information.
If an article is "open access" <license> information should also be given.
Example:
sect3.programlisting: <permissions> <copyright-year>2011</copyright-year> <copyright-holder>Macmillan Publishers Limited</copyright-holder> <license license-type="by-nc-nd-3.0" xlink:href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/ 3.0/" xlink:title="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/3.0/"> <license-p>This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-No Derivative Works 3.0 Unported License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creative commons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/3.0/<funding-source source-type="author-paid"/></license-p> </license> </permissions>
sect3.para: Correction articles should not contain license information as they are provided free of charge.

sect3.title: Correction articles
sect3.para: Correction articles (addendum, correction, corrigendum, erratum and retraction) should provide a link back to the corrected article using <related-article>.
See <related-article> for further information.

sect3.title: Abstracts
sect3.para: Do not use <label> as a child of <abstract>.
Subsections within abstracts should be captured as and , not <p><bold>.
@abstract-type should be used to identify alternative abstract types:

listitem.para: "standfirst"—A "standfirst" is an article summary, not a true abstract, that appears both in print and online
"editorial-summary"—An "editorial summary" is a professionally-written, 100-150 word summary of the article. It will usually have a title but no subsections.

sect3.para: Example 1: An abstract with no subsections
sect3.programlisting: The endosomal Toll-like receptors (TLRs) TLR3, TLR7, TLR8 and TLR9 are important in sensing foreign nucleic acids encountered by phagocytes. Because TLR8 was initially thought to be non-functional in mice, less is known about TLR8 than the genetically and functionally related TLR7. Originally associated with the recognition of single-stranded RNA of viral origin, there is now evidence that human TLR8 is also able to sense bacterial RNA released within phagosomal vacuoles, inducing the production of both nuclear factor (NF)-κB-dependent cytokines and type I interferons (IFNs), such as IFN-β. The functions of TLR8 extend beyond the recognition of foreign pathogens and include cross-talk with other endosomal TLRs, a process that may also have a role in the generation of autoimmunity.
sect3.para: Example 2: An abstract with subsections
sect3.programlisting:
Background:

Cannabinoid type-1 (CB1) receptor inverse agonists improve type 2 diabetes and dyslipidaemia but were discontinued due to adverse psychiatric effects. Δ9-Tetrahydro cannabivarin (THCV) is a neutral CB1 antagonist producing hypophagia and body weight reduction in lean mice. We investigated its effects in dietary-induced (DIO) and genetically (ob/ob) obese mice.

 Methods:

We performed two dose-ranging studies in DIO mice; study 1: 0.3, 1, 2.5, 5 and 12.5 mg  kg−1, oral twice daily for 30 days and study 2: 0.1, 0.5, 2.5 and 12.5 mg kg−1, oral, once daily for 45 days. One pilot (study 3: 0.3 and 3 mg kg−1, oral, once daily) and one full dose- ranging (study 4: 0.1, 0.5, 2.5 and 12.5 mg kg−1, oral, once daily) studies in ob/ob mice for 30 days. The CB1 inverse agonist, AM251, oral, 10 mg kg−1 once daily or 5 mg kg −1 twice daily was used as the positive control. Cumulative food and water intake, body weight gain, energy expenditure, glucose and insulin levels (fasting or during oral glucose tolerance tests), plasma high-density lipoprotein and total cholesterol, and liver triglycerides were measured. HL-5 hepatocytes or C2C12 myotubes made insulin-resistant with chronic insulin or palmitic acid were treated with 0, 1, 3 and 10 μM THCV or AM251.

 Results:

THCV did not significantly affect food intake or body weight gain in any of the studies, but produced an early and transient increase in energy expenditure. It dose-dependently reduced glucose intolerance in ob/ob mice and improved glucose tolerance and increased insulin sensitivity in DIO mice, without consistently affecting plasma lipids. THCV also restored insulin signalling in insulin-resistant hepatocytes and myotubes.

 Conclusions:

THCV is a new potential treatment against obesity-associated glucose intolerance with pharmacology different from that of CB1 inverse agonists/antagonists.
sect3.para: Example 3: A standfirst
sect3.programlisting: The war on emerging pathogens is intensifying in 2013.
sect3.para: Example 4: An editorial summary
sect3.programlisting:
Solar cells: Nanostructure enhancement

The performance of screen-printed silicon solar cells can be enhanced by aluminium nanoparticles. Xi Chen and co-workers from the Swinburne University of Technology in Australia report that light scattering effects can increase a solar cell’s short-circuit photocurrent density by up to 6.3%. Aluminium nanoparticles are advantageous because their Fano resonance, unlike those of gold or silver nanoparticles, falls in the ultraviolet wavelength band. This means that detrimental Fano interference effects between scattered and unscattered light can be avoided within the solar cell’s spectral range of operation. The addition of wrinkle-like graphene sheets further improves the photocurrent to 7.3% beyond that of an unmodified screen-printed cell.

sect2.title: Body structure
sect2.para: The body of an article may be a few paragraphs or contain sections and subsections.
Where the article has sections, each <sec> should have @specific-use giving the heading-level. Sub-sections should be nested within their parent element.
Example 1: Body with no sections
sect2.programlisting:
Not surprisingly, the recent guidelines from the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics (ACMG) regarding the return of incidental findings1 continue to generate controversy. At the heart of much of the controversy lies a single question: what makes a medical finding truly “incidental”?

Implicit in the new recommendations is a mandate to laboratories that when genome-scale sequencing is performed, the resultant data be actively and systematically queried for specific types of mutations in a selected set of genes. How can such a call for an active search be reconciled with the designation of those results as “incidental”? And why is this not tantamount to a call for overt screening for mutations in those genes? The details of how genome-scale sequencing is carried out, as well as long-established norms of clinical medical practice, are critical to resolving these questions.

Wave II (1996, n=14 738, aged 12–21 years, mean age 16.5 years) included by design Wave I adolescents still of school-age, including those currently in high school and high school drop outs.

Genetic markers used to determine ancestry were unavailable. As a proxy for ancestry, we used a race/ethnicity variable constructed using survey data on ancestral background and family relationship status from participants and their parents (that is, country of origin, length of time in the US, ancestry and adoption).

sect2.title: Lists
sect2.para:
For NPG/Palgrave article should always be contained in

and should not be a block-level element.
Do not use <label> or <title> in <list>.
<list> should have @list-type which can take the values "number", "bullet", "ucletter", "lcletter", "ucroman", "lcroman" or "none".
Do not use any other attributes on <list>.
Do not use <label> in <list-item>, as this symbol will be generated from the @list-type value. Do not use any attributes on <list-item>.

sect3.title: Display formulae
sect3.para:
Display formulae may be contained in

or be block-level elements outside

.
Do not use @id where the formulae is not numbered in the manuscript.
Example 1: An unnumbered formulae contained in

sect3.title: Inline formulae
sect3.para: Do not use any attributes on <inline-formula>.

sect2.title: References
sect2.para: A reference list (<ref-list>) is a series of references (<ref>). Generally each reference item contains only one citation element. As we currently have no standard style for punctuation in our journals, use <mixed-citation> for all references and retain punctuation..
<ref-list> should have @specific-use which takes the value "numero" (for numbered references) or "alpha" (for an alphabetical listing).
All <ref> elements should have an @id which should follow the format of "b" + number. Do not use <label>.
<mixed-citation> should have @publication-type which can take the value "journal", "book" or "other" (e.g. meeting reports, websites).
Where a reference has been written by a committee or other collaboration, use <collab collab-type="corporate-author">.
Do not use <comment> to mark-up punctuation or any other text, e.g. "(article in Japanese)".
Example:
sect2.programlisting: <ref-list specific-use="numero"> ... <ref id="b10"><mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><collab collab-type="corporate-author"> Committee to Evaluate Diagnostic Standards for Metabolic Syndrome</collab>. <article-title> Definition and the diagnostic standard for metabolic syndrome</article-title>. <source>Nippon Naika Gakkai Zasshi</source> <year>2005</year>; <volume>94</volume>: <fpage>794</fpage>– <lpage>809</lpage> (article in Japanese).</mixed-citation></ref> <ref id="b11"><mixed-citation publication-type="book"><string-name><surname>Christie</surname> <given-names>WW</given-names></string-name>. <source>Lipid Analysis: Isolation, Separation, Identification, and Structural Analysis of Lipids</source>, 3rd edn. <publisher-name>The Oily Press: Bridgwater</publisher-name>, <year>2003</year>.</mixed-citation></ref> <ref id="b38"><mixed-citation publication-type="other"><string-name><surname>Hoe</surname> <given-names>Y</given-names></string-name> Singapore's adult diabetes rate at 12-year high. (Internet) 2010 (cited 26 November 2010). <ext-link xlink:href="http://www.channelnewsasia.com/ stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1095709/1/.html" ext-link-type="url">http://www.channelnews asia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1095709/1/.html</ext-link>. (accessed 26 July 2012). </mixed-citation></ref> </ref-list>

sect1.title: Floating objects
sect1.para: All figures, illustrations, tables, boxes and supplementary material should be captured in <floats-group>.

sect2.title: Figures
sect2.para: Figures are the block-level objects that usually contain an image and are captured using <fig>.
Characteristics of a figure which should be captured within <floats-group>:

listitem.para: It has a label like "Figure 1" or "Graph 2".
It has a title or caption.
It is referenced by an <xref> with @ref-type="fig" in the article text.

sect2.para: Do not use <fig-group>.

sect3.para: <fig> should only contain the following optional child elements: <label>, <caption>, <alternatives>, <graphic>, and <attrib>.
The @id attribute should follow the format of "f" + the label number, e.g. id="f1". Do not use any other attributes on <fig>.

sect3.title: Label
sect3.para: <label> should only be used if the figure label is not of the standard "Figure" + number format, e.g. "Map 1". See Figure sample 1.
Do not use any attributes on <label>.

sect3.title: Caption
sect3.para: may contain and/or <p> child elements. <p> is used to capture introductory text or key information for the figure).
Do not use any attributes on <caption> or its child elements.

sect3.title: Images and slides
sect3.para: Capture the figure image(s) as <graphic> elements. If the figure has more than one image, they do not need to be wrapped in the <alternatives> tag, unless slide alternatives are also provided See Figure samples 1 and 2.
Only the main image should be referenced in the XML; do not include <graphic> elements for thumbails or other alternative image sizes.

Where a slide alternative is provided for an image, capture it as <supplementary-material> with attribute value @content-type="slide". The <graphic> and <supplementary-material> elements must then be wrapped in an <alternatives> tag. See Figure samples 3 and 4.

Other required attributes for both images and slides in figures:
position—must be ="anchor" for all images/slides in figures
xlink:href—image/slide filename, including the extension
mimetype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
mime-subtype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
Do not use any other attributes on <graphic> or <supplementary-material> within a figure.

Note: <supplementary-material> can also be used as a block-level element within <floats-group> to capture Supplementary Information. The markup requirements are different, so please see that section for more information.
See Figure samples 2, 3 and 4.

sect3.title: Attribution
sect3.para: Do not use any attributes on <attrib> within a figure.
See Figure sample 1.

sect4.title: Figure 1. Basic figure with non-standard label and attribution
sect4.programlisting: <fig id="f1"> <label>Map 1</label> <caption> <title>The Rural/Urban Definition for MSOAs in England</title> </caption> <graphic position="anchor" xlink:href="rt20112-f1.gif" mimetype="image" mime-subtype="gif"/> <attrib>Credit: UK Statistics Authority</attrib> </fig>

(A) Changes in plasma drug concentration and drug effect over time. (B) The difference in the concentration–effect relationship between the two time points (t1 and t2) when this relationship is modeled using pharmacodynamic model alone. (C) The estimation of effect compartment concentration in pharmacokinetic–pharmacodynamic modeling. (D) The concentration–effect relationship independent of the time point when the data are obtained.

sect4.programlisting: Heat map and hierarchical clustering of the relative protein abundances. Heat map presents the log2(abundance ratio). The plots present the time courses of the relative abundances of the proteins in the three treatment stages relative to the baseline. (a) Patient A: Thirty-eight proteins form a group with synchronously changing abundances (see thumbnail 5). (b) Patient B: Sixty-five proteins form a group with synchronously changing abundances (see thumbnail 1). In addition, there is a second group of 58 proteins with abundances growing dramatically in the ‘off’ stage (see thumbnail 6). Red—upregulated, green—downregulated.

sect3.title: Illustrations
sect3.para: Illustrations are image objects which appear in the article but are not usually mentioned in the text.
Characteristics of an illustration which should be captured within <floats-group>:

listitem.para: It does not have a label like "Figure 1" or "Graph 2".
It does not have a title, but it may have a caption and/or attribution.

It is referenced by an <xref> with @ref-type="other" in the article XML. @specific-use should also be stated on <xref>, to show the alignment of the image. Allowed values are "align-left", "align-center" and "align-right".

sect3.para: The illustration should be captured as <graphic> with @content-type="illustration".
The @id attribute should follow the format of "i" + number, e.g. id="i1".

Other required attributes for <graphic> with @content-type="illustration":
position—must be ="anchor" for all illustrations
xlink:href—illustration filename, including the extension
mimetype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
mime-subtype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
Do not use any other attributes on <graphic> with @content-type="illustration".
<graphic> may contain the following optional child elements: <caption> and <attrib>.

as a child element.
Do not use any attributes on <caption> or its child elements.
Example:
sect3.programlisting:
...

...

... reservation.

...

... ...

sect3.para: More information to be added here.

sect2.title: Tables
sect2.para: Tables are block-level objects that contain tabular material and are captured using <table-wrap>.
Characteristics of a table which should be captured within <floats-group>:

listitem.para: It has a label like "Table 1" or "Table D2.1".
It has a title or caption.
It is referenced by an <xref> with @ref-type="table" in the article text.

sect2.para: Do not use <table-wrap-group>.

sect3.title: Table wrapper
sect3.para: <table-wrap> should only contain the following optional child elements: <label>, <caption>, <oasis:table>, <alternatives>, <graphic>, <table-wrap-foot>, and <attrib>.
The @id attribute should follow the format of "t" + the label number, e.g. id="t1" or id="tD2.1". Do not use any other attributes on <table-wrap>.

sect3.title: Label
sect3.para: <label> should only be used if the table label is not of the standard "Table" + number format, e.g. "Exhibit 1". See Table sample 1.
Do not use any attributes on <label>.

sect3.title: Caption
sect3.para: <caption> must contain <title>.

An optional

element may also be used to capture any additional introductory text for the table.
Do not use any attributes on <caption> or its child elements.

sect3.title: Table body
sect3.para: The JATS DTD normally uses the HTML table model. As NPG uses the OASIS CALS model, the "oasis" namespace is required on the table element and all of its descendants.
A detailed tag library for the OASIS Open Exchange CALS Table Model can be found at: http://jats.nlm.nih.gov/options/OASIS/tag-library/19990315/index.html

A table body may be captured as XML (<oasis:table>), an image (<graphic>) and there may also be a slide alternative for the image (<supplementary-material>). Where two or more of these representations are used, they should be wrapped in an <alternatives> tag. See Table samples 4, 5 and 6.

sect4.para: The @frame attribute value should be given. Do not use any other attributes on <oasis:table>.
The @cols attribute value is required by the DTD. Do not use any other attributes on <oasis:tgroup>.
Values for the following attributes must be declared: @colnum, @colname, @align.
Values may be declared for the following attributes: @char (only if @align="char"), @colsep, @rowsep.
Do not use @colwidth or @charoff.
The @valign attribute is only required if it is "top" or "middle". The default value ("bottom") does not need to be stated.
The @valign attribute is only required if it is "bottom" or "middle". The default value ("top") does not need to be stated.
An empty <oasis:entry/> element should be used to show an empty cell.
@break may be used to aid formatting of the output.
@namest and @nameend should be used to show where entries span a number of columns. @align must also be declared for spanning entries.
Values may also be declared for the following attributes where they are different to the values in the corresponding <oasis:colspec>: @align, @char, @colsep, @rowsep.
Do not use @colwidth, @charoff or @morerows.

sect3.title: Images and slides
sect3.para: Where an image file is provided for the table, capture this as <graphic>. If the image is to be used for display purposes, rather than <oasis:table>, the attribute value @specific-use="show" must be used.
Where a slide alternative is also provided for the table image, capture this as <supplementary-material> with attribute value @content-type="slide".

Other required attributes for both images and slides in tables:
position—must be ="anchor" for all images/slides in tables
xlink:href—image/slide filename, including the extension
mimetype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
mime-subtype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
Do not use any other attributes on <graphic> or <supplementary-material> within a table.

Note: <supplementary-material> can also be used as a block-level element within <floats-group> to capture Supplementary Information. The markup requirements are different, so please see that section for more information.
See Table samples 3, 4, 5 and 6.

sect3.title: Table footer
sect3.para:
should only contain and/or

child elements.

sect4.title: Table footnotes
sect4.para: Table footnotes should be captured in <table-wrap-foot>, not as the final row(s) of <oasis:tbody>.
Do not wrap footnotes in the <fn-group> tag.
The footnote should contain a <label> containing the reference symbol, letter or number.

The @id attribute should follow the format of "t#-fn#" where "t#" is the table @id and "fn#" represents the order of the footnote in the table, e.g. id="t1-fn2" or id="tD2.1-fn6". Do not use any other attributes on <fn> within <table-wrap-foot>.
See Table samples 5 and 6.

sect4.title: Other footer text
sect4.para:
may also contain paragraphs of information about the table that appear after the last row. These should be captured as

.

Do not use any attributes on

within .
See Table samples 2 and 5.

sect3.title: Table attribution
sect3.para: Table attribution information should be captured in <attrib> as a child of <table-wrap> and not within <table-wrap-foot>.
Do not use any attributes on <attrib> within a table.
See Table sample 1.

sect2.title: Supplementary information
sect2.para: Supplementary items are block-level objects that contain additional information relating to an article and are captured using <supplementary-material>.
Characteristics of supplementary material which should be captured at the end of <floats-group>:

listitem.para: It has a title like "Supplementary Information" or "Supplementary Figures 1–12".
It may also have a legend or description.
It may be referenced by an <xref> with @ref-type="supplementary-material" in the article text.

sect2.para: The only allowed child of is . must always contain and may also contain <p> to contain the legend/description). Do not use any other possible child elements of <supplementary-material>.

Required attributes for supplementary material:
id—should follow the format of "s" + number, e.g. id="s1", id="s2" etc
content-type—takes the values "image", "document", "archive", "text", "movie" or "other" as follows:
Supplementary material content types
content typefile extensions
imageeps, gif, jpg, jpeg, bmp, png, pict, ps, tiff, wmf
documentdoc, docx, pdf, pps, ppt, pptx, xls, xlsx
archivetar, tgz, zip
textc, csv, htm, html, rtf, txt, xml
movieaiff, au, avi, midi, mov, mp2, mp3, mp4, mpa, mpg, noa, qt, ra, ram, rv, swf, wav, wmv
othercif, exe, pdb, sdf, sif
xlink:href—filename, including the extension
mimetype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
mime-subtype—based on the filename extension. See Mimetypes and mime subtypes for the correct mappings.
Examples:
sect2.programlisting:
Supplementary Method Supplementary Figure 1 Supplementary Figure 2 Supplementary Table 1 Supplementary Movie Supplementary Data

This data was recorded during Experiment 2.

 Data Record
sect2.para: Note: <supplementary-material> can also be used as a descendant element within <fig> or <table-wrap> to capture information about powerpoint slides. The markup requirements are different, so please see Figure and Table sections for more information.

sect1.title: Sub-articles
sect1.para: <sub-article> is not required for our online academic journals. This section will be expanded upon when we start producing other journals using the JATS DTD.

chapter.title: Elements
chapter.para: These XML elements have specific style rules associated with them not covered by the information in the previous section.

sect1.para: The root element for all articles.
The @article-type attribute is required, e.g. @article-type="oa". [This is the equivalent of categ/@id in the NPG Article DTD, and arttype/@arttype in the AJ DTD.]
attributes:

listitem.para: article-type—(#REQUIRED)
xml:lang—"en" is the default and does not need to be explicitly stated; use "de" for German and "ja" for Japanese (Kanji)
xmlns:mml—Fixed value "http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"
xmlns:oasis—Fixed value "http://docs.oasis-open.org/ns/oasis-exchange/table"
xmlns:xlink—Fixed value "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"

sect1.para: Used to tag link information to objects outside of the article. The text may be a repeat of the content in the @xlink:href or it may be different.
Required attributes:

listitem.para: @xlink:href—Holds an identifier of or locator to an object available through or at that resource.
@ext-link-type—set as "url" for a link to a website (starting with "http:" or "/"); "ftp" for a link to an ftp site

sect1.para: Example:
sect1.programlisting: Analyses were performed off-line using the National Institutes of Health program, Image J (http://rsbweb.nih.gov/ij ).

sect1.para: Contains the ISSN(s) for the journal.
Articles must have at least one <issn>.
If a journal has a print and electronic ISSN, include in successive <issn> tags.
attributes:

listitem.para: pub-type—Set as "ppub" for a print ISSN and "epub" for an electronic ISSN. (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: See Journal metadata for examples of markup.
This element takes the value of the journal pcode, e.g. "nutd" for Nutrition & Diabetes, "nneuro" for Nature Neuroscience.
attributes:

listitem.para: journal-id-type—Set as "publisher". (#REQUIRED)

sect1.para: See Journal metadata for examples of markup.
The complete title of the journal in which the article is published should be contained in the child <journal-title> element.
Do not use <abbrev-journal-title>, <journal-subtitle> or <trans-title-group>.
See Journal metadata for examples of markup.
The publisher name ("Nature Publishing Group", "Palgrave Macmillan") should be contained in the child <publisher-name> element.
Do not use <publisher-loc>.
See Journal metadata for examples of markup.
Links to related articles (for example, articles which have had a corrigendum).
Required attributes:

listitem.para: related-article-type—takes the value "is-erratum-to", "is-correction-to", "is-retraction-to", "is-addendum-to" or "is-corrigendum-to"
xlink:href—the doi for the referenced article
ext-link-type—takes the value "doi"

sect1.para: Example:
Used to reference objects within the article. Do not include emphasis or punctuation within the element.
attributes:

listitem.para: ref-type—This is the @id of the referenced object. (#REQUIRED)
rid—see the table above for allowed values and ID/IDREF prefixes. (#REQUIRED)
specific-use—This is only used when linking to an illustration to show the alignment of the image. Allowed values are "align-left", "align-center" and "align-right".
id—Do not use.

sect2.title: Author affiliation, correspondence and notes
sect2.para: Where <xref> is used to link to affiliation [@ref-type="aff"] and correspondence [@ref-type="corresp"] information, it should be empty as the link numbering can be derived from the @ids.

Where <xref> is used to link to author notes [@ref-type="author-notes"] (e.g. equal contribution or current address information), it should contain the superscript number or symbol used in the manuscript.
See Contributors and affiliations for example markup.

sect2.title: Bibliographic references
sect2.para: Where <xref> is used to link to bibliographic references, it should always contain the text for the link (i.e. not be empty).
Where a range of references are given in the text, @rid should contain multiple values, but the text of <xref> will just contain the range itself.

table.title: Example markup for <xref> to bibliographic references

entry.tag: text,<sup><xref ref-type="bibr" rid="b10">10</xref>,<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="b12">12</xref>,<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="b19">19</xref></sup>
text)<sup><xref ref-type="bibr" rid="b9">9</xref>,<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="b21 b22 b23 b24">21–24</xref></sup>,
(<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="b10">Ronco <italic>et al</italic>, 2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="b13">Siebers <italic>et al</italic>, 2009</xref>)

sect2.title: Table footnotes
sect2.para: Where <xref> is used to link to table footnotes, it should always contain the label for the link (i.e. not be empty).
See table samples 5 and 6 for example markup of <xref ref-type="table-fn">.
